**G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, § 4**.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County under **G.L. c. 223, § 1**, as the Premises are located in Springfield, and the acts and omissions giving rise to this complaint occurred within this county.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, a landlord may not directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and any such interference constitutes a violation entitling the tenant to actual and statutory damages.

**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law in all residential leases in Massachusetts. See **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.support_reasoning: The opinion plainly assumes and applies an implied covenant/warranty of quiet enjoyment in these residential leases and discusses its breach, but it does not expressly state that such a covenant is implied by law in *all* residential leases in Massachusetts. The focus is on whether the landlord’s conduct amounted to a breach/constructive eviction, not on articulating a broad rule that every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment as a matter of law. Thus it is consistent with, but not clear authority for, the universal proposition claimed.
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises “for a substantial time” (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge.

**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.proposition: A landlord violates the covenant where his or her conduct, or failure to act, “substantially interferes with the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment.” **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment and explains that liability arises for serious interferences with the tenant’s tenancy that impair the character and value of the leased premises, regardless of specific malicious intent. While the exact quoted phrase “substantially interferes with the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment” does not appear verbatim, the court adopts the traditional formulation that quiet enjoyment protects against substantial interferences with the tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment, and treats the repeated flooding as such an interference. Thus, the case is properly cited for that substantive standard.
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 41.raw_text: **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994);
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 41.proposition: Liability under **G.L. c. 186, § 14** may arise from inaction or neglect where the landlord allows uninhabitable conditions to persist. See **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); **Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 41.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the quiet enjoyment statute) and holds that a landlord’s omissions can create liability where they allow a seriously interfering condition to persist. The Court explains that a breach may be the “natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord “failed to do,” and specifically states that if the landlord “stood idle” and took no or inadequate measures to remove persons whose unlawful activities seriously interfered with tenants’ use of the premises, it may be liable under § 14. This squarely supports liability arising from inaction or neglect in the face of uninhabitable (or seriously interfering) conditions.
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 41.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

**Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Liability under **G.L. c. 186, § 14** may arise from inaction or neglect where the landlord allows uninhabitable conditions to persist. See **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994); **Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
**Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that the landlord’s failure to provide heat—regardless of financial inability or specific intent—constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14’s quiet enjoyment protections. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling, and imposes liability where the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s actions (or failure to act) is interference with the tenant’s rights. This aligns with the proposition that liability may arise from allowing uninhabitable conditions (lack of heat) to persist through inaction or neglect.
**Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment…. It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… Thus…liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to…a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14….”

**G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A**.proposition: The existence of defective electrical wiring is a material defect affecting habitability under **G.L. c. 239, § 8A**, **105 C.M.R. 410.351**, and **410.750**, which require landlords to maintain electrical systems in good repair.

**105 C.M.R. 410.351**.proposition: The existence of defective electrical wiring is a material defect affecting habitability under **G.L. c. 239, § 8A**, **105 C.M.R. 410.351**, and **410.750**, which require landlords to maintain electrical systems in good repair.

410.750.proposition: The existence of defective electrical wiring is a material defect affecting habitability under **G.L. c. 239, § 8A**, **105 C.M.R. 410.351**, and **410.750**, which require landlords to maintain electrical systems in good repair.

**Lipsitt v. Plaud**, 466 Mass. 240 (201.proposition: The landlord’s failure to remedy known defects may constitute interference under **Lipsitt v. Plaud**, 466 Mass. 240 (2013)**, and **Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1991)**.
**Lipsitt v. Plaud**, 466 Mass. 240 (201.support_reasoning: Lipsitt v. Plaud is about whether the Massachusetts Wage Act preempts common-law contract and quasi-contract claims for unpaid wages and about veil piercing. It does not involve landlord-tenant relations, defects in leased premises, or any concept of interference by a landlord. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that a landlord’s failure to remedy known defects may constitute interference; that concept comes, if at all, from other cases such as Haddad v. Gonzalez, not from Lipsitt.
**Lipsitt v. Plaud**, 466 Mass. 240 (201.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we are asked to decide whether G. L. c. 149, §§ 148 and 150 (Wage Act), are intended to be the exclusive remedy for the recovery of unpaid wages under Massachusetts law, preempting common-law breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims. We conclude that they are not.”

**Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1.proposition: The landlord’s failure to remedy known defects may constitute interference under **Lipsitt v. Plaud**, 466 Mass. 240 (2013)**, and **Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1991)**.
**Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1.support_reasoning: Haddad concerns landlord liability for breach of the implied warranty of habitability, G.L. c. 186, §§ 14 and 18, and c. 93A (including intentional infliction of emotional distress), but it does not analyze or even mention the concept of “interference” as later discussed in Lipsitt v. Plaud or under §14’s interference-with-quiet-enjoyment framework in a way that ties failure to repair, standing alone, to an ‘interference’ element. The decision focuses on habitability, retaliation, emotional distress, and damages, not on defining when a landlord’s failure to remedy known defects constitutes actionable interference. Thus, it does not provide direct authority for the specific interference proposition stated.
**Haddad v. Gonzalez**, 410 Mass. 855 (1.relevant_excerpt: Haddad offered to rent Gonzalez an apartment that was essentially uninhabitable; Gonzalez moved in only after Haddad's agent told her that repairs would be made. The apartment had many defects, including non-functioning heat, peeling lead paint, broken windows and doors, hazardous flooring, irregular hot water, cockroaches, and rodents. Gonzalez's requests for repairs were largely ignored.... In these circumstances... the judge was justified in concluding that Gonzalez had made out a common law case of intentional infliction of emotional distress.

**Winchester v. O\u2019Brien**, 266 Mass.proposition: The covenant also protects the tenant’s right to freedom from substantial interference caused by the landlord’s neglect. See **Winchester v. O’Brien**, 266 Mass. 33 (1929); **Tripp v. Keith**, 217 Mass. 164 (1914)**.
**Winchester v. O\u2019Brien**, 266 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes an implied obligation that landlords refrain from acts they voluntarily undertake which substantially impair the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment, and it allows recovery in tort and equity for such wrongful interference. But the court treats this as an implied term arising from the grant of the lease and as wrongful nuisance/trespass, and explicitly distinguishes the claim from being based solely on breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment; it does not frame the landlord’s *neglect* as the basis of liability or clearly tie this principle to the covenant itself. Thus it does not cleanly support the specific proposition that the covenant protects against substantial interference caused by the landlord’s neglect.
**Winchester v. O\u2019Brien**, 266 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant for which injunctive relief might be sought or an action of tort would lie. … It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises and appurtenant rights by the acts done or authorized by the defendants.”

**Tripp v. Keith**, 217 Mass. 164 (1914).proposition: The covenant also protects the tenant’s right to freedom from substantial interference caused by the landlord’s neglect. See **Winchester v. O’Brien**, 266 Mass. 33 (1929); **Tripp v. Keith**, 217 Mass. 164 (1914)**.

**Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 37.proposition: Plaintiffs in similar cases have recovered damages for loss of use of part of the premises and consequential damages. See **Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); **Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)**.
**Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 37.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that plaintiffs have recovered damages for loss of use of part of the premises and consequential damages. Berman is a rent-abatement/breach of implied warranty of habitability case; it discusses abatement measured by the diminished rental value but does not address or award separate damages for loss of use of part of the premises or consequential damages. The opinion even notes that, aside from the timing of abatement, damages were not in dispute, and it does not analyze categories of consequential damages.
**Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 37.relevant_excerpt: “The trial judge found that the measure of damages was ‘the difference between the value of the apartment as warranted and the rental value of the apartment in its defective condition.’ … Apart from the question whether the tenant’s rent abates only after the landlord has had a reasonable time to repair, damages are not in dispute in this case.”

**Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Plaintiffs in similar cases have recovered damages for loss of use of part of the premises and consequential damages. See **Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); **Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)**.
**Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns plaintiffs recovering damages for loss of use of part of the premises and consequential damages. Jablonski v. Casey does not involve any award of damages to the tenant; instead, the court affirms findings of no breach of the warranty of habitability, no breach of quiet enjoyment, no retaliatory eviction, and no c. 93A violation, and upholds the landlord’s judgment for possession and back rent. The opinion therefore does not discuss, endorse, or award loss-of-use or consequential damages and does not support the cited proposition.
**Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt:
Finally, in the absence of a breach of the warranty of habitability or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and with no finding of retaliatory eviction by York, we agree with the trial judge that no violation of G. L. c. 93A, § 2(a), occurred.
...
Upon review of all the evidence, we conclude that the trial judge did not abuse her discretion and that there was sufficient evidence to support her findings.
